editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nicole Sheriko

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter two serving-men, Peter and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I would we were removed from this town, Anthony
That we might taste some quiet: for mine own part,
I'm almost melted with continual trotting
After inquiries, dreams, and revelations,
Of who knows, whom or where? serve wenching soldiers,
That know no other paradise but plackets:
I'll serve a priest in Lent, first and eat bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thou art the froward'st fool —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why good tame Anthony?
Tell me but this: to what end came we hither?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To wait upon our masters.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: But how Anthony?
Answer me that; resolve me there good Anthony?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To serve their uses.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Show your uses Anthony.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To be employed in any thing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No Anthony,
Not any thing I take it; nor that thing
We travel to discover, like new islands;
A salt itch serve such uses; in things of moment,
Concerning things I grant ye, not things errant,
Sweet ladies things, and things to thank the surgeon:
In no such things, sweet Anthony, put case —

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Come, come, all will be mended: this invisible woman
Of infinite report for shape and virtue,
That bred us all this trouble to no purpose,
They are determined now no more to think on,
But fall close to their studies.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Was there ever
Men known to run mad with report before?
Or wonder after that they know not where
To find? or if found, how to enjoy? are men's brains
Made nowadays of malt, that their affections
Are never sober? but like drunken people
Founder at every new fame? I do believe too
That men in love are ever drunk, as drunken men
Are ever loving.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Prithee be thou sober,
And know, that they are none of those, not guilty
Of the least vanity of love, only a doubt
Fame might too far report, or rather flatter
The graces of this woman, made them curious
To find the truth, which since they find so blotted
And locked up from their searches, they are now settled
To give the wonder ever.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would they were settled
To give me some new shoes too: for I'll be sworn
These are e'en worn out to the reasonable souls
In their good worship's business: and some sleep
Would not do much amiss, unless they mean
To make a bellman on me: and what now
Mean they to study, Anthony, moral philosophy
After their mar-all women?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Mar a fool's head.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twill mar two fools heads, and they take not heed,
Besides the giblets to 'em.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Will you walk sir,
And talk more out of hearing? your fool's head
May chance to find a wooden nightcap else.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I never lay in any. Enter don John and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then leave your lying,
And your blind prophesying: here they come,
You had best tell them as much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am no tell-tale. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I would we could have seen her though: for sure
She must be some rare creature, or report lies,
All men's reports too,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I could well wish I had seen her;
But since she is so concealed, so beyond venture
Kept and preserved from view, so like a paradise,
Placed where no knowledge can come near her; so guarded
As 'twere impossible, though known to reach her,
I have made up my belief.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hang me from this hour
If I more think upon her, or believe her,
But as she came a strong report unto me,
So the next fame shall lose her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the next way:
But whither are you walking?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: My old round
After my meat, and then to bed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis healthfull.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Will not you stir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Upon my life this lady still —

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Then you will lose it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Pray let's walk together.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now I cannot.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I have something to impart.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An hour hence
I will not miss to meet you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ith' high street;
For not to lie, I have a few devotions
To do first, than I am yours.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Remember. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Antonio, and two gent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cut his windpipe, I say.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Fie Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or knock his brains out first, then forgive him
If you do thrust, be sure it be to th' hilts,
A surgeon may see through him.
You are too violent,
Too open, undiscreet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Am I not ruined?
The honour of my house cracked? my blood poisoned?
My credit, and my name?
Be sure it be so,
Before ye use this violence. Let not doubt,
And a suspecting anger so much sway ye,
Your wisdom may be questioned.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I say kill him,
And then dispute the cause; cut off what may be,
And what is, shall be safe.
Hang up a true man,
Because 'tis possible he may be thievish:
Alas, is this good justice?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I know as certain,
As day must come again; as clear as truth.
And open as belief can lay it to me,
That I am basely wronged, wronged above recompense;
Maliciously abused, blasted for ever
In name and honour, lost to all remembrance,
But what is smeared, and shameful; I must kill him,
Necessity compels me.
But think better

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: There is no other cure left: yet witness with me
All that is fair in man, all that is noble,
I am not greedy of this life I seek for,
Nor thirst to shed man's blood; and would 'twere possible
I wish it with my soul, so much I tremble
To offend the sacred image of my maker,
My sword could only kill his crimes: no 'tis honour,
Honour, my noble friends, that idol honour,
That all the world now worships, not Petruchio
Must do this justice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it once be done,
And 'tis no matter, whether you, or honour,
Or both be accessary.
Do you weigh Petruchio
The value of the person, power, and greatness,
And what this spark may kindle?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To perform it,
So much I am tied to reputation,
And credit of my house, let it raise wild-fires,
That all this dukedom smoke, and storms that toss me
Into the storms of everlasting ruin,
Yet I must through; if ye dare side me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You're friends indeed, if not.
Here's none flies from you,
Do it in what design ye please, we'll back ye.
But then be sure ye kill him.
Is the cause
So mortal, nothing but his life?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Believe me,
A less offence has been the desolation
Of a whole name.
No other way to purge it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There is, but never to be hoped for,
Think an hour more,
And if then ye find no safer road to guide ye,
We'll set up our rests too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine's up already,
And hang him for my part,
Goes less than life.
If we see noble cause, 'tis like our swords
May be as free and forward as your words. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The civil order of this town Bellonia
Makes it beloved, and honoured of all travellers,
As a most safe retirement in all troubles;
Beside the wholesome seat, and noble temper
Of those minds that inhabit it, safely wise,
And to all strangers virtuous: but I see
My admiration has drawn night upon me,
And longer to expect my friend may pull me
Into suspicion of too late a stirrer,
Which all good governments are jealous of.
I'll home, and think at liberty: yet certain,
'Tis not so far night as I thought; for see,
A fair house yet stands open, yet all about it
Are close, and no lights stirring: there may be foul play:
I'll venture to look in: if there be knaves,
I may do a good office. Woman within.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: What? how is this?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur Fabritio?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I'll go nearer.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: This is a woman's tongue, here may be good done.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Who's there?
Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: O come, for heaven's sake!

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I must see what this means,

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I have stayed this long hour for you, make no noise,
For things are in strange trouble: here, be secret,
'Tis worth your care; begone now; more eyes watch us,
Then may be for our safeties.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hark ye?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Peace: good night.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: She is gone, and I am loaden; fortune for me;
It weighs well, and it feels well; it may chance
To be some pack of worth: by th' mass 'tis heavy;
If it be coin or jewels, 'tis worth welcome:
I'll never refuse a fortune: I am confident
'Tis of no common price: now to my lodging:
If it hit right, I'll bless this night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,
I cannot meet him; sure he has encountered
Some light of love or other, and there means
To play at in and in for this night. Well don John,
If you do spring a leak, or get an itch,
Till ye claw off your curled pate, thank your night-walks:
You must be still a boothaling: one round more,
Though it be late, I'll venture to discover ye,
I do not like your outleaps.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome to town, are ye all fit?
To point sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where are the horses?
Where they were appointed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be private, and whatsoever fortune
Offer itself, let's stand sure.
Fear not us,
'Ere ye shall be endangered, or deluded,
We'll make a black night on't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more, I know it;
You know your quarters?
Will you go alone sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ye shall not be far from me, the least noise
Shall bring ye to my rescue.
We are counselled. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Was ever man so paid for being curious?
Ever so bobbed for searching out adventures,
As I am? did the devil lead me? must I needs be peeping
Into men's houses where I had no business,
And make myself a mischief? 'tis well carried;
I must take other men's occasions on me,
And be I know not whom: most finely handled:
What have I got by this now? what's the purchase?
A piece of evening arras work, a child,
Indeed an infidel: this comes of peeping:
A lump got out of laziness; good white bread
Let's have no bawling with ye: 'sdeath, have I
Known wenches thus long, all the ways of wenches,
Their snares and subtleties? have I read over
All their school learnings, dived into their quiddits,
And am I now bumfiddled with a bastard?
Fetched over with a card of five, and in mine old days,
After the dire massacre of a million
Of maidenheads? caught the common way, ith' night too
Under another's name, to make the matter
Carry more weight about it? well don John,
You will be wiser one day, when ye have purchased
A bevy of these butter prints together,
With searching out concealed iniquities,
Without commission: why, it would never grieve me,
If I had got this gingerbread: never stirred me,
So I had had a stroke for't: 't had been justice
Then to have kept it; but to raise a dairy
For other men's adulteries, consume myself in candles,
And scouring works, in nurse's bells and babies,
Only for charity, for mere I thank you,
A little troubles me: the least touch for it,
Had but my breeches got it, had contented me.
Whose e'er it is, sure it had a wealthy mother,
For 'tis well clothed, and if I be not cozened,
Well lined within: to leave it here were barbarous,
And ten to one would kill it: a more sin
Than his that got it: well, I will dispose on't,
And keep it, as they keep deaths heads in rings,
To cry, memento to me; no more peeping.
Now all the danger is to qualify
The good old gentlewoman, at whose house we live,
For she will fall upon me with a catechism
Of four hours long: I must endure all;
For I will know this mother: come good wonder,
Let you and I be jogging: your starved treble
Will waken the rude watch else: all that be
Curious night-walkers, may they find my fee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sure he's gone home:
I have beaten all the purlieus,
But cannot bolt him: if he be a bobbing
'Tis not my care can cure him: tomorrow morning
I shall have further knowledge from a surgeon's —
Where he lies moored, to mend his leaks.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: I'm ready,
And through a world of dangers am flown to ye.
Be full of haste and care, we are undone else:
Where are your people? which way must we travel?
For heaven's sake stay not here sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What may this prove?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Alas I am mistaken, lost, undone.
For ever perished. Sir, for heaven's sake tell me,
Are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Of this place?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, born in Spain.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As ever you loved honour,
As ever your desires may gain their ends,
Do a poor wretched woman but this benefit,
For I am forced to trust ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You've charmed me,
Humanity and honour bids me help ye;
And if I fail your trust. —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The time's too dangerous
To stay your protestations: I believe ye,
Alas, I must believe ye: from this place,
Good noble sir, remove me instantly,
And for a time, where nothing but yourself,
And honest conversation may come near me,
In some secure place settle me. What I am,
And why thus boldly I commit my credit
Into a stranger's hand, the fears and dangers,
That force me to this wild course, at more leisure
I shall reveal unto you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come, be hearty,
He must strike through my life that takes ye from me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He will sure come. Are ye well armed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never fear us.
Here's that will make 'em dance without a fiddle.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are to look for no weak foes, my friends,
Nor unadvised ones.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Best gamesters make the best game,
We shall fight close and handsome then.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Antonio,
You are a thought too bloody.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? all physicians
And penny almanacs allow the opening
Of veins this month: why do ye talk of bloody?
What come we for, to fall to cuffs for apples?
What, would ye make the cause a cudgel quarrel?
On what terms stands this man? is not his honour
Opened to his hand, and picked out like an oyster?
His credit like a quart pot knocked together,
Able to hold no liquor? clear but this point.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Speak softly, gentle cousin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll speak truly;
What should men do allied to these disgraces,
Lick o'er his enemy, sit down, and dance him?
You are as far o'th' bow hand now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And cry;
That's my fine boy, thou wilt do so no more child.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here are no such cold pities.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By saint Jaques
They shall not find me one: here's old tough Andrew,
A special friend of mine, and he but hold,
He strike 'em such a hornpipe: knocks I come for,
And the best blood I light on; I profess it,
Not to scar costermongers; if I lose mine own,
Mine audits lost, and farewell five and fifty.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let's talk no longer, place yourselves with silence,
As I directed ye; and when time calls us,
As ye are friends, so show yourselves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So be it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 9.
div.stage: Enter don John and his landlady.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Nay son, if this be your regard.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Good mother.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Good me no goods; your cousin, and yourself
Are welcome to me, whilst you bear yourselves
Like honest and true gentlemen: bring hither
To my house, that have ever been reputed
A gentlewoman of a decent, and fair carriage,
And so behaved myself?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know ye have.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Bring hither, as I say, to make my name
Stink in my neighbour's nostrils? your devices,
Your brats, got out of Alligant, and broken oaths?
Your linsey Woolsey work, your hasty puddings?
I fosler up your filched iniquities?
You're deceived in me, sir, I am none
Of those receivers.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Have I not sworn unto you,
'Tis none of mine, and showed you how I found it?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ye found an easy fool that let you get it,
She had better have worn pasterns.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Will ye hear me?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Oaths? what do you care for oaths to gain your ends,
When ye are high and pampered? What saint know ye?
Or what religion, but your purposed lewdness,
Is to be looked for of ye? nay, I will tell ye,
You will then swear like accused cutpurses,
As far of truth too; and lie beyond all falconers:
I'm sick to see this dealing.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Heaven forbid mother.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Nay, I am very sick.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir.Within.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Bring down the bottle of canary wine.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Exceeding sick, heaven help me.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Haste ye sirrah,
I must e'en make her drunk; nay gentle mother;

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Now fie upon ye, was it for this purpose
You fetched your evening walks for your digestions,
For this pretended holiness? no weather,
Not before day could hold ye from the matins.
Were these your bopeep prayers? ye have prayed well,
And with a learned zeal: watched well too; your saint
It seems was pleased as well: still sicker, sicker.
sp.stage: Enter Anthony with a bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There is no talking to her till I have drenched her.
Give me: here mother take a good round draught,
'Twill purge spleen from your spirits: deeper mother.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ay, ay, son; you imagine this will mend all.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: All i'faith mother.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I confess the wine
Will do his part.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I'll pledge ye.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: But son John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know your meaning mother; touch it once more,
Alas you look not well; take a round draught,
It warms the blood well, and restores the colour,
And then we'll talk at large.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: A civil gentleman?
A stranger? one the town holds a good regard of?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Nay I will silence there.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: One that should weigh his fair name? o, a stichl

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There's nothing better for a stitch, good mother,
Make no spare of it, as you love your health,
Mince not the nutter.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: As I said, a gentleman,
Lodge in my house? now heavens my comfort, signior!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I looked for this.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I did not think you would have used me thus;
A woman of my credit: one, heaven knows,
That loved you but too tenderly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Dear mother,
I ever found your kindness, and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: No, no, I am a fool to counsel ye. Where's the infant?
Come, let's see your workmanship.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: None of mine, mother.
But there 'tis, and a lusty one.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Heaven bless thee,
Thou hadst a hasty making; but the best is,
'Tis many a good man's fortune: as I live
Your own eyes signior, and the nether lip
As like ye, as ye had spit it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Bless me, what things are these?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I thought my labour
Was not all lost, 'tis gold, and these are jewels,
Both rich, and right I hope.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Well, well son John,
I see ye are a woodman, and can choose
Your dear, though it be i'th dark, all your discretion
Is not yet lost; this was well clapped aboard:
Here I am with you now; whenas they say
Your pleasure comes with profit; when ye must needs do,
Do where ye may be done to, 'tis a wisdom
Becomes a young man well: be sure of one thing,
Lose not your labour and your time together,
It seasons of a fool, son, time is precious,
Work wary whilst ye have it; since ye must traffic
Sometimes this slippery way, take sure hold signior,
Trade with no broken merchants, make your lading,
As you would make your rest, adventurously,
But with advantage ever.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: All this time mother,
The child wants looking too, wants meat and nurses.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Now blessing of thy care; it shall have all,
And instantly; I'll seek a nurse myself, son;
'Tis a sweet child: ah my young Spaniard;
Take you no further care sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yes of these jewels,
I must by your leave mother: these are yours,
To make your care the stronger: for the rest
I'll find a master; the gold for bringing up on't,
I freely render to your charge.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: No more words,
Nor no more children, (Good son) as you love me,
This may do well.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I shall observe your morals.
But where's don Ferdinand (Mother)

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ten to one
About the like adventure: he told me.
He was to find you out. Exit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why should he stay thus?
There may be some ill chance in't: sleep I will not,
Before I have found him: now this woman's pleased,
I'll seek my friend out, and my care is eased. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Believe sir, 'tis as possible to do it,
As to remove the city; the main faction,
Swarm through the streets like hornets, armed with angers
Able to ruin states: no safety left us,
Nor means to die like men, if instantly
You draw not back again,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May he be drawn
And quartered too, that turns now; were I surer
Of death than thou art of thy fears, and with death
More than those fears are too.
Sir, I fear not.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I would not crack my vow, start from my honour,
Because I may find danger; wound my soul,
To keep my body safe.
I speak not sir,
Out of a baseness to you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No, nor do not
Out of a baseness leave more: what is danger,
More than the weakness of our apprehensions?
A poor cold part o'th blood? who takes it hold of?
Cowards, and wicked livers: valiant minds
Were made the masters of it, and as hearty seamen
In desperate storms, stem with a little rudder
The tumbling ruins of the ocean:
So with their cause and swords do they do dangers.
Say we year sure to die all in this venture,
As I am confident against it: is there any
Amongst us of so fat a sense, so pampered,
Would choose luxuriously to lie a-bed ,
And purge away his spirit, send his soul out
In sugar-lops, and syrups? give me dying,
As dying out to be, upon mine enemy,
Parting with mankind, by a man that's manly:
Let 'em be all the world, and bring along
Cain's envy with 'em, I will on.
You may sir,
But with what safety?
Since 'tis come to dying,
You shall perceive sir, here be those amongst us
Can die as decently as other men,
And with as little ceremony: on brave sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That's spoken heartily.
And he that flinches
May he die lousy in a ditch.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more dying,
There's no such danger in it:
What's o'clock ?
Somewhat above your hour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away then quickly,
Make no noise, and no trouble will attend us. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 11.
div.stage: Enter Frederick, and Peter, (With a candle.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give me the candle: so go you out that way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What have we now to do?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And of your life sirrah,
Let none come near the door without my knowledge,
No not my land lady, nor my friend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nor any serious business that concerns me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Is the wind there again?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now enter without fear. — and noble lady
That safety and civility ye wished for
Shall truly here attend you: no rude tongue
Nor rough behaviour knows this place, no wishes
Beyond the moderation of a man,
Dare enter here: your own desires and innocence,
Joined to my vowed obedience, shall protect you,
Were dangers more than doubts.

sp.speaker: Coast
sp.l: Ye are truly noble,
And worth a woman's trust: let it become me,
(I do beseech you sir) for all your kindness,
To render with my thanks, this worthless trifle;
I may be longer troublesome.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fair offices
Are still their own rewards: heaven bless me lady
From selling civil courtesies: may it please ye,
If ye will force a favour to oblige me,
Draw but that cloud aside, to satisfy me
For what good angel I am engaged,

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: It shall be.
For I am truly confident ye are honest:
The piece is scarce worth looking on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Trust me
The abstract of all beauty, soul of sweetness,
Defend me honest thoughts, I shall grow wild else:
What eyes are there, rather what little heavens,
To stir men's contemplations? what a paradise
Runs through each part she has? good blood be temperate:
I must look off: too excellent an object
Confounds the sense that sees it noble lady,
If there be any further service to cast on me,
Let it be worth my life, so much I honour ye,
Or the engagement of whole families.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Your service is too liberal, worthy sir,
Thus far I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Command me lady.
You make your power too poor.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: That presently
With all convenient haste, you would retire
Unto the street you found me in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: There, if you find a gentleman oppressed
With force and violence, do a man's office,
And draw your sword to rescue him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He's safe,
Be what he will, and let his foes be devils,
Armed with your pity, I shall conjure 'em.
Retire, this key will guide ye: all things necessary
Are there before ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: All my prayers go with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye clap on proof upon me: men say gold
Does all, engages all, works through all dangers:
Now I say beauty can do more: the King's exchequer,
Nor all his wealthy Indies, could not draw me
Through half those miseries this piece of pleasure
Might make me leap into: we are all like sea-cards,
All our endeavours and our motions,
(As they do to the North) still point at beauty,
Still at the fairest: for a handsome woman,
(Setting my soul aside ) it should go hard,
But I would strain my body: yet to her,
Unless it be her own free gratitude,
Hopes ye shall die, and thou tongue rot within me,
Ere I infringe my faith: now to my rescue. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, pursued by Petruchio, Antonio, and that faction.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You will not all oppress me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Kill him ith' wanton eye: let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then ye shall buy me dear.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I say cut his weazand spoil his peeping.
Have at your lovesick heart sir. Enter don John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Sure 'tis fighting.
My friend may be engaged: fie gentlemen,
This is unmanly odds.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll stop your mouth sir. Du. falls down, don Joh. bestrides him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nay, then have at thee freely:
There's a plumb sir to satisfy your longing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away: I hope I have sped him: here comes rescue.
We shall be endangered: where's Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must have one thrust more sir.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Come up to me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A mischief confound your fingers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well:
Has given me my quiet us est, I felt him
In my small guts, I'm sure, has feezed me:
This comes of siding with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Can you go sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I should go man, and my head were of,
Never talk of going.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come, all shall be well then. Enter the Duke's faction.
I hear more rescue coming.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's turn back then;
My skull's uncloven yet, let me but kill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away for heaven's sake with him.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well sir,
Only a little staggered.

sp.speaker: Faction Duke
sp.l: Let's pursue 'em.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No not a man, I charge ye: thanks good coat,
Thou hast saved me a shrewd welcome: 't was put home too,
With a good mind I'm sure on't.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Are ye safe then?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My thanks to you brave sir, whose timely valour,
And manly courtesy came to my rescue,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ye 'Had foul play offered ye, and shame befall him
That can pass by oppression.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May I crave sir,
But thus much honour more, to know your name?
And him I am so bound to?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: For the bond sir,
'Tis every good man's tie: to know me further
Will little profit ye; I am a stranger,
My country Spain; my name don John, a gentleman
That lies here for my study.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I have heard sir,
Much worthy mention of ye, yet I find
Fame short of what ye are.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: You are pleased sir,
To express your courtesy: may I demand
As freely what you are, and what mischance
Cast you into this danger?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: For this present
I must desire your pardon: you shall know me
Ere it be long sir, and a nobler thanks,
Then now my will can render.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Your will's your own sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What is't you look for sir, have ye lost any thing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Only my hat i'th scuffle; sure these fellows
Were night-snaps.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No, believe sir: pray ye use mine,
For 'twil be hard to find your own now.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Indeed ye shall, I can command another:
I do beseech ye honour me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I will sir,
And so I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Within these few days
I hope I shall be happy in your knowledge.
Till when I love your memory. Exit Duke, etc. enter Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I yours.
This is some noble fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis his tongue sure.
Don John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Don Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye 'Are fairly met sir:
I thought ye had been a batfowling: prithee tell me,
What revelations hast thou had tonight ,
That home was never thought of?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Revelations?
I'll tell thee Fredrick. but before I tell thee,
Settle thy understanding.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis prepared, sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why then mark what shall follow. This night Fredr.
This bawdy night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thought no less.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: This blind night,
What dost think I have got?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The pox it may be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Would 'twere no worse: ye talk of revelations,
I have got a revelation will reveal me,
An arrant coxcomb while I live.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is't?
Thou hast lost nothing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No, I have got I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What hast thou got?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: One of the infantry, a child.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A chopping child, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Give ye joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A lump of lewdness Fredrick, that's the truth on't:
This town's abominable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I still told ye John
Your whoring must come home; I counselled ye:
But where no grace is —

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: 'Tis none o'mine, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Answer the parish so.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Cheated introth.
Peeping into a house, by whom I know not,
Nor where to find the place again: no Fredricke,
Had I but kissed the ring fort; 'tis no poor one,
That's my best comfort, for't has brought about it
Enough to make it man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: At home.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A saving voyage: but what will you say signior,
To him that searching out your serious worship,
Has met a stranger fortune?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: How, good Frederick?
A militant girl now to this boy would hit it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, mine's a nobler venture: what do you think sir
Of a distressed lady, one whose beauty
Would oversell all Italy?

sp.speaker: Joh,
sp.l: Where is she —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A woman of that rare behaviour,
So qualified, as admiration
Dwells round about her: of that perfect spirit —

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I marry sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That admirable carriage,
That sweetness in discourse; young as the morning,
Her blushes staining his.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But where's this creature?
Show me but that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That's all one, she's forth coming,
I have her sure boy.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hark ye Fredrick.
What truck betwixt my infant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis too light sir,
Stick to your charges good don John, I am well.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But is there such a wench?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: First tell me this,
Did ye not lately as ye walked along,
Discover people that were armed, and likely
To do offence?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Yes marry, and they urged it
As far as they had spirit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray go forward.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: A gentleman I found engaged amongst 'em,
It seems of noble breeding, I'm sure brave mettle,
As I returned to look you, I set in to him,
And without hurt (I thank heaven) rescued him,
And came myself off safe too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My work's done then:
And now to satisfy you, there is a woman,
O John, there is a woman —

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: O, where is she?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And one of no less worth than I assure ye;
And which is more, fallen under my protection.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I am glad of that: forward sweet Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And which is more than that, by this nights wand'ring,
And which is most of all, she is at home too sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Come, let's be gone then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, but 'tis most certain,
You cannot see her, John.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She has sworn me
That none else shall come near her: not my mother
Till some few doubts are cleared.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Not look upon her? What chamber is she in?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In ours.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Let's go I say:
A woman's oaths are wafers, break with making,
They must for modesty a little: we all know it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, I'll assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Not see her?
I smell an old dog trick of yours, well Fredrick,
Ye talked to me of whoring, let's have fair play,
Square dealing I would wish ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: When 'tis come.
Which I know never will be, to that issue,
Your spoon shall be as deep as mine sir.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Tell me,
And tell me true, is the cause honourable,
Or for your ease?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By all our friendship, John,
'Tis honest, and of great end.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am answered:
But let me see her though: leave the door open
As ye go in.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not wide open,
But just so, as a jealous husband
Would level at his wanton wife through.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: That courtesy,
If ye desire no more, and keep it strictly,
I dare afford ye: come, 'tis now near morning. Ex.

div.head: Scene 2.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay the old woman's gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's a caterwauling
Among the gutters: but conceive me, Peter,
Where our good masters should be?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where they should be,
I do conceive, but where they are, good Anthony —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ay, there it goes: my master's bopeep with me,
With his sly popping in and out again,
Argued a cause, a frippery cause.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Believe me,
They bear up with some carvel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do believe thee,
For thou hast such a master for that chase,
That till he spend his main mast —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray remember
Your courtesy good Anthony; and withal,
How long 'tis since your master sprung a leak,
He had a sound one since he came. Lute sounds within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dost not hear a lute?
Again?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Above in my master's chamber.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There's no creature: he hath the key himself man.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: This is his lute: let him have it. Sing within a little.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I grant you; but who strikes it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: An admirable voice too, hark ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Anthony,
Art sure we are at home?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Without all doubt, Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then this must be the devil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it be. Sing again.
Good devil sing again: oh dainty devil,
Peter believe it, a most delicate devil,
The sweetest devil —Enter Fredrick and don John.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If ye could leave peeping.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I cannot by no means.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then come in softly,
And as ye love your faith, presume no further
Than ye have promised.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Basto.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What make you up so early sir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: You sir in your contemplations.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O pray ye peace sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why peace sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: 'Tis your lute.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray ye speak softly.
She's playing on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The house is haunted sir,
For this we have heard this half year.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye saw nothing;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor I sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Get us our breakfast then,
And make no words on't; we'll undertake this spirit,
If it be one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is no devil Peter. Sing. Exeunt servants.
Mum, there be bats abroad.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, now she sings.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: An angel's voice I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why didst thou shrug so?
Either allay this heat; or as I live
I will not trust ye.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Pass: I warrant ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To curse those stars, that men say govern us,
To rail at fortune, fall out with my fate,
And task the general world, will help me nothing:
Alas, I am the same still, neither are they
Subject to helps, or hurts: our own desires
Are our own fates, our own stars, all our fortunes,
Which as we sway 'em, so abuse, or bless us.

div.stage: Enter Fredrick, and don John peeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace to your meditations.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Pox upon ye,
Stand out oth' light.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I crave your mercy sir,
My mind o'ercharged with care made me unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray ye set that mind at rest, all shall be perfect.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I like the body rare; a handsome body,
A wondrous handsome body: would she would turn:
See, and that spiteful puppy be not got
Between me and my light again,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis done,
As all that you command shall be: the gentleman
Is safely off all danger.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: O de dios.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How shall I thank ye sir? how satisfy?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Speak softly, gentle lady, all's rewarded,
Now does he melt like marmalade.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis certain,
Thou art the sweetest woman I e'er looked on:
I hope thou art not honest.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: None disturbed ye?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Not any sir, nor any sound came near me,
I thank your care.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I would fain pray now,
But the devil and that flesh there, of the world,
What are we made to suffer?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: He'll enter;
Pull in your head and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hark ye Fredricke,
I have brought ye home your packsaddle.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pox upon ye.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nay let him enter: fie my lord the Duke,
Stand peeping at your friends.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ye are cozened lady,
Here is no Duke.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I know him full well signior.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hold thee there wench.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This mad-brained fool will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace come in.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: My grace,
There was a word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Shall he enter,
Whoe'er he be?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Well followed Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in then. Enter don John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Bless ye lady:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay start not, though he be a stranger to ye,
He's of a noble strain, my kinsman, lady,
My countryman, and fellow traveller,
One bed contains us ever, one purse feeds us,
And one faith free between us; do not fear him,
He's truly honest.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: That's a lie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And trusty:
Beyond your wishes: valiant to defend,
And modest to converse with, as your blushes.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now may I hang myself; this commendation
Has broke the neck of all my hopes: for now
Must I cry, no forsooth, and I forsooth, and surely,
And truly as I live,, and as I am honest.
Has done these things for 'Nonce too; for he knows,
Like a most envious rascal as he is,
I am not honest, nor desire to be,
Especially this way: has watched his time,
But I shall quit him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Sir, I credit ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go kiss her John.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Plague of your commendations.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, I shall now desire to be a trouble.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Never to me, sweet lady: thus I seal
My faith, and all my service.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: One word signior.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now 'tis impossible I should be honest,
She kisses with a conjuration
Would make the devil dance: what points she at?
My leg I warrant, or my well knit body:
Sit fast don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Twas given him by that gentleman
You took such care of; his own being lost ith' scuffle.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With much joy may he wear it: 'tis a right one,
I can assure ye gentleman, and right happy
May you be in all fights for that fair service.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why do ye blush?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'T had almost cozened me,
For not to lie, when I saw that, I looked for
Another master of it: but 'tis well. Knock within.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who's there? Ent. Anthony.
Stand ye a little close: come in sir,
Now what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: There is a gentlemen without,
Would speak with don John,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Who sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do not know sir, but he shows a man
Of no mean reckoning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let him show his name,
And then return a little wiser.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well sir. Exit Anthony.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How do you like her John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: As well as you Fredrick,
For all I am honest: you shall find it so too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Art thou not honest?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Art thou an ass?
And modest as her blushes? What a blockhead
Would e'er have popped out such a dry apology,
For his dear friend? and to a gentlewoman,
A woman of her youth, and delicacy.
They are arguments to draw them to abhor us.
An honest moral man; 'tis for a constable:
A handsome man, a wholesome man, a tough man,
A liberal man, a likely man, a man
Made up like Hercules, unslaked with service:
The same tonight , tomorrow night, the next night,
And so to perpetuity of pleasures,
These had been things to hearken too, things catching:
But you have such a spiced consideration,
Such qualms upon your worship's conscience,
Such chilblains in your blood, that all things pinch ye,
Which nature, and the liberal world makes custom,
And nothing but fair honour, oh sweet honour,
Hang up your eunuch honour: that I was trusty,
And valiant, were things well put in; but modest!
A modest gentleman I o wit where wast thou?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am sorry John,

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My lady's gentlewoman
Would laugh me to a schoolboy, make me blush
With playing with my codpiece point: fie on thee,
A man of thy discretion?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It shall be mended:
And henceforth ye shall have your due. Enter Anthony.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I look fort: how now, who is't?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A gentleman of this town
And calls himself Petruchio. Enter Constantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I'll attend him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How did he call himself.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Petruchio,
Does it concern you ought?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O gentlemen,
The hour of my destruction is come on me,
I am discovered, lost, left to my ruin:
As ever ye had pity —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Do not fear,
Let the great devil come, he shall come through me:
Lost here, and we about ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fall before us?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O my unfortunate estate, all angers
Compared to his, to his —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let his, and all men's,
Whilst we have power and life: stand up for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have offended heaven too; yet heaven knows —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: We are all evil:
Yet heaven forbid we should have our deserts.
What is 'a?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Too too near to my offence sir;
Oh he will cut me piecemeal.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis no treason?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Let it be what it will: if a cut here,
I'll find him cutwork.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He must buy you dear,
With more than common lives.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Fear not, nor weep not:
By heaven I'll fire the town before ye perish,
And then, the more the merrier, we'll jog with ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in, and dry your eyes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Pray no more weeping:
Spoil a sweet face for nothing? my return
Shall end all this I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Heaven grant it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This man should be of special rank:
For these commends carry no common way,
No slight worth with 'em:
'A shall be he. Ent. don John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Save ye sir: I am sorry
My business was so unmannerly, to make ye
Wait thus long here.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Occasions must be served sir:
But is your name don John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: It is sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then,
First, for your own brave sake I must embrace ye:
Next, from the credit of your noble friend
Hernando de Aluara, make ye mine:
Who lays his charge upon me in this letter
To look ye out, and for the goodness in ye,
Whilst your occasions make ye resident
In this place, to supply ye, love and honour ye;
Which had I known sooner —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Noble sir,
You'll make my thanks too poor: I wear a sword, sir,
And have a service to be still disposed of,
As you shall please command it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
That manly courtesy is half my business:
And to be short, to make ye know I honour ye,
And in all points believe your worth like oracle,
And how above my friends, which are not few,
And those not slack, I estimate your virtues,
Make yourself understand, this day Petruchio,
A man that may command the strength of this place,
Hazard the boldest spirits; hath made choice
Only of you, and in a noble office.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Forward, I am free to entertain it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thus then:
I do beseech ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I shall do it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ferrara's Duke, would I might call him worthy ,
But that he has razed out from his family,
As he has mine with infamy, this man,
Rather this powerful monster, we being left
But two of all our house, to stock out memories,
My sister, and myself; with arts, and witchcrafts,
Vows, and such oaths heaven has no mercy for,
Drew to dishonour this weak maid, by stealths,
And secret passages I knew not of,
Oft he obtained his wishes, oft abused her:
I am ashamed to say the rest: this purchased,
And his hot blood allayed, as friends forsake us
At a mile's end upon our way, he left her,
And all our name to ruin.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: This was foul play,
And ought to be rewarded so.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope so;
He scaped me yesternight: which if he dare
Again adventure for, heaven pardon him,
I shall with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: For me, brave signior,
What do ye intend?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Only, fair sir, this trust,
Which from the commendations of this letter,
I dare presume well placed, nobly to bear him
By word of mouth a single challenge from me,
That man to man, if he have honour in him,
We may decide all difference.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Fair, and noble,
And I will do it home: when shall I visit ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Please you this afternoon, I will ride with ye:
For at a castle six mile hence, we are sure
To find him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I'll be ready.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To attend ye,
My man shall wait: with all myEx. Petr. enter Fredr.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My service shall not fail ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: All's well: who dost thou think this wench is?
Guess, and thou canst?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Be it known then,
To all men by these presents, this is she,
She, she, and only she, our curious coxcombs
Were errant two months after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who, Constantia?
Thou talkest of cocks and bulls.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I talk of wenches,
Of cocks and hen's don Frerdick; this is the pullet
We two went proud after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: It shall be;
Sister to don Petruchio: I know all man.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now I believe.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Go to, there has been stirring,
Fumbling with linen Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible,
You know her feign was pure as fire.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: That pure fire
Has melted out her maidenhead: she is cracked:
We have all that hope of our side, boy.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Thou tellest me,
To my imagination, things incredible:
I see no loose thought in her.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: That's all one,
She is loose ith' hilts by heaven: but the world must know
A fair way, upon vow of marriage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: There may be such a slip.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: And will be Fredrick,
Whilst the old game's a foot: I fear the boy too
Will prove hers too I took up.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good circumstance
May cure all this yet.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: There thou hitst it, Fredrick:
Come, let's walk in and comfort her: her being here
Is nothing yet suspected: anon I'll tell thee
Wherefore her brother came, who by this light
Is a brave noble fellow, and what honour
Has done to me a stranger: there be irons
Heating for some, will hist into their heart bloods,
'Ere all be ended; so much for this time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well sirExeunt.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Come ye do know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I do not by this hand mistress.
But I suspect.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: That if eggs continue
At this price, women will never be saved
By their good works.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ye shall, any thing
Lies in my power: the Duke of Lorraine now
Is seven thousand strong: I heard it of a fishwife,
A woman of fine knowledge.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: The Pope's bulls are broke loose too and 'tis suspected
They shall be baited in England.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, 'tis not so well neither.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: But I say to ye,
Who is it keeps your master company?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say to you, don John.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I say what woman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say so too.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I say again, I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say 'tis fit ye should.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: And I tell thee
He has a woman here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And I tell thee
'Tis then the better for him.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: You are no bawd now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would I were able to be called unto it:
A worshipful vocation for my elders;
For as I understand it is a place
Fitting my betters far.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Was ever gentlewoman
So frumped off with a fool? well saucy sirrah,
I will know who it is, and for what purpose;
I pay the rent, and I will know how my house
Comes by these inflammations: if this gear hold,
Best hang a signpost up, to tell the signiors,
Here ye may have lewdness at livery. Ent. Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.l: 'Twould be a great ease to your age.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?
Why what's the matter landlady?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: What's the matter?
Ye use me decently among ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who has abused her, you sir?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: 'Ods my witness
I will not be thus treated, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I gave her no ill language.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Thou liest lewdly,
Thou tookst me up at every word I spoke,
As I had been a malkin, a flirt Gillian;
And thou thinkst, because thou canst write and read,
Our noses must be under thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Dare you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let but the truth be known sir, I beseech ye,
She raves of wenches, and I know not what sir:

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Go to, thou knowest too well, thou wicked varlet,
Thou instrument of evil.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: As I live sir,
She is ever thus till dinner.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Get ye in,
I'll answer you anon sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: By this hand
I'll break your posset pan. Exit.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Then by this hood
I'll lock the meat up.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now your grief, what is't?
For I can guess —

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ye may with shame enough,
If there were shame amongst ye; nothing thought on,
But how ye may abuse my house: not satisfied
With bringing home your bastards to undo me,
But you must drill your whores here too; my patience
Because I bear, and bear, and carry, all,
And as they say am willing to groan under)
Must be your makesport now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more of these words.
Nor no more murmurings lady: for you know
That I know something. I did suspect your anger,
But turn it presently and handsomely,
And bear yourself discreetly to this woman,
For such a one there is indeed.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: 'Tis well son.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leaving your devils matins, and your melancholies,
Or we shall leave our lodgings.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: You have much need
To use these vagrant ways, and to much profit:
Ye had that might content
(At home within yourselves too) right good gentlemen,
Wholesome, and ye said handsome: but you gallants,
Boast that I was to believe ye —

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leave your suspicion:
For as I live there's no such thing.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Mine honour;
And 'twere not for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Come, your honour,
Your house, and you too, if you dare believe me
Are well enough: sleek up yourself, leave crying,Bowl of wipe ready.
For I must have ye entertain this lady
With all civility, she well deserves it,
Together with all secrecy: I dare trust ye,
For I have found ye faithful: when you know her
You will find your own fault; no more words, but do it.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: You know you may command me. Ent. don. Joh.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Worshipful lady,
How does thy velvet scabbard? by this hand
Thou lookest most amiably: now could I willingly
And 'twere not for abusing thy Geneva print there,
Venture my body with thee.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: You'll leave this ropery,
When you come to my years.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: By this light
Thou art not above fifteen yet, a mere girl,
Thou hast not half thy teeth: come —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee John
Let her alone, she has been vexed already:
She'll grow stark mad man.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I would see her mad,
An old mad woman

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee be patient.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Is like a miller's mare, troubled with toothache.
She'll make the rarest faces.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go, and do it,
And do not mind this fellow.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Well don John.
There will be times again; when oh good mother,
What's good for a carnosity in the bladder?
O the green water, mother.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Doting take ye,
Do ye remember that?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She has paid ye now sir.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Clarry, sweet mother, clarry.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Are ye satisfied?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I'll never whore again; never give petticoats
And waistcoats at five pound a piece; good mother,
Quickly mother: now mock on son.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: A devil grind your old chaps. Exit land.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By this hand wench
I'll give thee a new hood for this.
Has she met with your lordship?
Touchwood rake her. Enter Anthony.
She's a rare ghostly mother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Below attends ye
The gentleman's man sir that was with ye.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Well sir;
My time is come then: yet if my project hold,
You shall not stay behind: I'll rather trust. Enter Constan.
A cat with sweet milk Fredrick; by her face
I feel her fears are working.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Is there no way,
I do beseech ye think yet, to divert
This certain danger?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible:
Their honours are engaged.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then there must be murder,
Which, gentlemen, I shall no sooner hear of,
Then make one in't: you may, if you please sir,
Make all go less yet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Lady were't mine own cause,
I could dispense: but loaden with my friends trust,
I must go on; though general massacres
As much I fear —

sp.speaker: Const,
sp.l: Do ye hear sir; for heaven's pity
Let me request one love of you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes any thing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This gentleman I find too resolute,
Too hot, and fiery for the cause, as ever
You did a virtuous deed, for honour's sake
Go with him, and allay him: your fair temper
And noble disposition, like wished showers,
May quench those eating fires, that would spoil all else.
I see in him destruction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will do it;
And 'tis a wise consideration,
To me, a bounteous favour: hark ye John,
I will go with ye.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Indeed I will,
Ye go upon a hazard: no denial;
For as I live, I'll go.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Then make ye ready,
For I am straight a horseback.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My sword on,
I am as ready as you: what my best labour,
With all the art I have can work upon 'em,
Be sure of, and expect fair end: the old gentlewoman
Shall wait upon you; she is both grave and private,
And ye may trust her in all points.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Ye are noble:
And so I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: That seal for me too,
And I hope happy issue lady.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: All heavens care upon ye, and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: So,
Now my mind's at rest.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Away, 'tis late John. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antonio, a surgeon, and 2. Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Come sir ▪ be hearty: all the worst is past.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me some wine.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: 'Tis death sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a horse sir.
'Sblood, to be dressed to the tune of ale only,
Nothing but sauces to my sores.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Fie Antonio,
You must be governed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has given me a damned glister,
Only of sand and snow water, gentlemen,
Has almost scoured my guts out.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I have given you that sir
Is fittest for your state.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And here he feeds me
With rotten ends of rooks, and drowned chickens,
Stewed pericraniums, and pia-maters;
And when I go to bed, by heaven 'tis true gentlemen,
He rolls me up in lints, with labels at 'em,
That I am just the man ith' almanac,
In head and face, is Aries place.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Will't please ye
To let your friends see ye opened?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will it please you sir
To let me have a wench: I feel my body
Open enough for that yet?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: How, a wench?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why look ye gentlemen; thus I am used still,
I can get nothing that I want.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Leave these things,
And let him open ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: D'ye hear surgeon?
Send for the music, let me have some pleasure
To entertain my friends, beside your salads,
Your green salves, and your searches, and some wine too,
That I may only smell to it: or by this light
I'll die upon thy hand, and spoil thy custom.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Let him have music. Ent. Rowl. with wine.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: 'Tis ith' house, and ready,
If he will ask no more: but wine —Music.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: He shall not drink it.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Will these things please ye?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and let 'em sing
John Dorrie.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: 'Tis too long.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll have John Dorrie,
For to that warlike tune I will be opened.
Give me some drink, have ye stopped the leaks well surgeon,
All will run out else?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Fear not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit down gentlemen:
And now advance your plasters. Song of Joh. Dorry.
Give 'em ten shillings friends: how do ye find me?
What symptoms do you see now?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: None sir, dangerous:
But if you will be ruled —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What time?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I can cure ye
In forty days, so you will not transgress me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a dog shall lick me whole in twenty:
In how long canst thou kill me?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do it; there's more delight in't.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: You must have patience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Man, I must have business; this foolish fellow
Hinders himself: I have a dozen rascals
To hurt within these five days: good man mender,
Stop me up with parsley, like stuffed beef,
And let me walk abroad.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Ye shall walk shortly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For I must find Petruchio.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Time enough.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Come lead him in, and let him sleep: within these three days
We'll beg ye leave to play.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: And then how things fall,
We'll certainly inform ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But surgeon promise me
I shall drink wine then too.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: A little tempered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I'll no tempering surgeon,

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Well, as't please ye,
So ye exceed not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell: and if ye find
The mad slave, that thus slashed me, commend me to him,
And bid him keep his skin close.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Take your rest sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have told ye all I can, and more than yet
Those gentlemen know of me; ever trusting
Your council and concealment: for to me
You seem a worthy woman; one of those
Are seldom found in our sex, wise and virtuous,
Direct me I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ye say well lady,
And hold ye to that point; for in these businesses
A woman's council that conceives the matter,
(Do ye mark me, that conceives the matter lady)
Is worth ten men's engagements: she knows something '
And out of that can work like wax: when men
Are giddy-headed, either out of wine,
Or a more drunkenness, vain ostentation,
Discovering all: there is no more keep in 'em,
Then hold upon an eels tail: nay 'tis held fashion
To defame now all they can.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ay, but these gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Do not you trust to that: these gentlemen
Are as all gentlemen of the same barrel:
Ay, and the self same pickle too. Be it granted,
They have used ye with respect and fair behaviour,
Yet since ye came: do you know what must follow?
They are Spaniards, lady, gennets of high mettle,
Things that will thrash the devil, or his dam,
Let 'em appear but cloven.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now heaven bless me.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Mad colts will court the wind: I know 'em lady
To the least hair they have; and I tell you,
Old is I am, let but the pint pot bless 'em,
They'll offer to my years —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Such rude gambols —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To you?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ay, and so handle me, that oft I am forced
To fight of all four for my safety: there's the younger,
Don John, the arrantst Jack in all this city:
The other, time has blasted, yet he will stoop,
If not o'erflown, and freely on the quarry;
Has been a dragon in his days. By'r Tarmont,
Don Jenkin is the devil himself, the dog-days,
The most incomprehensible whoremaster,
Twenty a night is nothing: beggars, broom-women,
And those so miserable, they look like famine,
Are all sweet ladies in his drink.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's a handsome gentleman.
Pity he should be master of such follies.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: He's never without a noise of syringes
In's pocket, those proclaim him; birding pills,
Waters to cool his conscience, in small viols;
With thousand such sufficient emblems: the truth is,
Whose chastity he chops upon, he cares not.
He flies at all; bastards upon my conscience,
He has now in making multitudes; the last night
He brought home one; I pity her that bore it,
But we are all weak vessels, some rich woman
(For wise I dare not call her) was the mother,
For it was hung with jewels: the bearing cloth
No less than crimson velvet.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: 'Tis true lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Was it a boy too?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: A brave boy; deliberation
And judgement showed in's getting, as I'll say for him,
He's as well paced for that sport —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: May I see it?
For there is a neighbour of mine, a gentlewoman,
Has had a late mischance, which willingly
I would know further of; now if you please
To be so courteous to me.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Ye shall see it:
But what do ye think of these men now ye know 'em,
And of the cause I told ye of? Be wise,
Ye may repent too late else; I but tell ye
For your own good, and as you will find it lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am advised.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: No more words then; do that,
And instantly, I told ye of be ready:
Don John, I'll fit ye for your frumps,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I shall be:
But shall I see this child?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Within this half hour,
Let's in, and there think better; she that's wise,
Leaps at occasion first; the rest pay for it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, don John. and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Sir, he is worth your knowledge; and a gentleman
If I that so much love him, may commend him,
Of free and virtuous parts; and one, if soul play
Should fall upon us, for which fear I brought him,
Will not fly back for Phillip's.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ye much honour me,
And once more I pronounce ye both mine.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, what troop
Is that below i'th valley there?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Hawking I take it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: They are so; 'tis the Duke, 'tis even he gentlemen,
Sirrah, draw back the horses till we call ye,
I know him by his company.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I think too
He bends up this way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: So he does.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Stand you still
Within that covert till I call: you Fredrick,
By no means be not seen, unless they offer
To bring on odds upon us; he comes forward,
Here will I wait him fairly: to your cabins.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I need no more instruct ye?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Fear me not,
I'll give it him, and boldly. Ex: Pet. and Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Feed the hawks up,
We'll fly no more today: oh my blessed fortune,
Have I so fairly met the man!

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ye have sir,
And him you know by this,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sir all the honour,
And love —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I do beseech your grace stay there,
(For I know you too now) that love and honour
I come not to receive; nor can you give it,
Till ye appear fair to the world; I must beseech ye
Dismiss your train a little.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Walk aside,
And out of hearing I command ye: now sir,

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Last time we met, I was a friend.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And nobly
You did a friend's office: let your business
Be what it may, you must be still —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Your pardon,
Never a friend to him, cannot be friend
To his own honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: In what have I transgressed it?
Ye make a bold breach at the first sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Bolder,
You made that breach that let in infamy
And ruin, to surprise a noble stock.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be plain sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I will, and short;
Ye have wronged a gentleman
Little behind yourself, beyond all justice,
Beyond mediation of all friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The man, and manner of wrong?
John Petruchio,
The wrong, ye have whored his sister.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's his will in't?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: His will is to oppose you like a gentleman,
And single, to decide all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now stay you sir,
And hear me with the like belief: this gentleman
His sister that you named, 'tis true I have long loved,
Nor was that love lascivious, as he makes it;
As true, I have enjoyed her: no less truth
I have a child by her: but that she, or he,
Or any of that family are tainted
Suffer disgrace, or ruin, by my pleasures,
I wear a sword to satisfy the world no,
And him in this cause when he please; for know sir,
She is my wife, contracted before heaven,
(Witness I owe more tie to, than her brother)
Nor will I fly from that name, which long since
Had had the church's approbation,
But for his jealous danger.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Sir, your pardon,
And all that was my anger, now my service.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fair sir, I knew I should convert ye; had we
But that rough man herd now too —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: And ye shall sir
Whoa, hoa, ho.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hope ye have laid no ambush? Enter Petru.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Only friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My noble brother welcome:
Come put your anger off, we'll have no fighting,
Unless you will maintain I am unworthy
To bear that name.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Do you speak this heartily?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Upon my soul, and truly; the first priest
Shall put you out of these doubts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now I love ye;
And I beseech you pardon my suspicions,
You are now more than a brother, a brave friend too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: The good man's overjoyedEnter Fred.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now, how goes it?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why, the man 'Has his mare again, and all's well Fredrick,
The Duke professes freely he's her husband.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes, for modest gentlemen.
I must present ye: may it please your grace
To number this brave gentleman, my friend
And noble kinsman, amongst those your servants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O my brave friend! you shower your bounties on me
Amongst my best thoughts signior, in which number
You being worthily disposed already,
May place your friend to honour me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My love sir,
And where your grace dares trust me, all my service.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why? this is wondrous happy: but now brother,
Now comes the bitter to our sweet: Constantia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor what, nor where, do I know?
Winged with her fears last night, beyond my knowledge,
She quit my house, but whether —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let not that —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more good sir, I have heard too much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay sink not,
She cannot be so lost.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Nor shall not gentlemen;
Be free again, the lady's found; that smile sir,
Shows ye distrust your servant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do beseech ye.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ye shall believe me: by my soul she is safe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven knows, I would believe sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may safely.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: And under noble usage: this fair gentleman
Met her in all her doubts last night, and to his guard
(Her fears being strong upon her) she gave her person,
Who waited on her, to our lodging; where all respect,
Civil and honest service now attend her.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: Ye may believe now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes, I do, and strongly:
Well my good friends, or rather my good angels,
For ye have both preserved me; when these virtues
Die in your friend's remembrance —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Good your grace
Lose no more time in compliment, 'tis too precious,
I know it by myself, there can be no hell
To his that hangs upon his hopes; especially
In way of lustily pleasures.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has hit it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: To horse again then, for this night I'll crown
With all the joys ye wish for.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Happy gentlemen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This is the maddest mischief: never fool
Was so fobbed off, as I am; made ridiculous,
And to myself, mine own ass: trust a woman,
I'll trust the devil first; for he dare be
Better than's word sometime: what faith have I broke?
In what observance failed? Let me consider,Enter don John. and Fred.
For this is monstrous usage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let them talk,
We'll ride on fair and softly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well Constantia,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Constantia, what's this fellow? stay by all means.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye have spun yourself a fair thread now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stand still John.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What cause had you to fly? what fear possessed ye?
Were you not safely lodged from all suspicion?
Used with all gentle means? did any know
How ye came thither, or what your sin was.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: John.
Smell some juggling John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes, Fredricks, I fear it will be found so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So strangely,
Without the counsel of your friends; so desperately
To put all dangers on ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis she.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So deceitfully
After a stranger's lure?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Did ye mark that Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To make ye appear more monster; and the law
More cruel to reward ye? to leave all,
All that should be your safeguard, to seek evils?
Was this your wisdom? this your promise? well
He that incited ye —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Mark that too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Had better have ploughed farther off; now lady,
What will your last friend, he that should preserve ye,
And hold your credit up, the brave Antonio,
Think of this slip? he'll to Petruchio,
And call for open justice.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Tis she Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But what that he is John.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do not doubt yet
To bolt ye out, for I know certainly
Ye are about the town still: ha, no more words. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Discreetly.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Finely carried.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have no more of these tricks?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ten to one sir,
I shall meet with 'em if ye have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Is this honest?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Was it in you a friend's part to deal double?
I am no ass don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And don John,
It shall appear I am no fool;
Disgrace me to make yourself a lecher?
'Tis boyish, 'tis base.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Tis false, and most unmanly to upbraid me,
Nor will I be your bolster sir,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou wanton boy, thou hadst better have been eunuch,
Thou common woman's courtesy, then thus
Lascivious, basely to have bent mine honour.
A friend? I'll make a horse my friend first!

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Holla, holla,
Ye kick to fast sir: what strange brains have you got,
That dare crow out thus bravely? I better been a eunuch?
I privy to this dog trick? clear yourself,
For I know where the wind sits, and most nobly,
Or as I have a life —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more: they're horses. A noise within like horses.
Nor show no discontent: tomorrow comes;
Let's quietly away: if she be at home,
Our jealousies are put off.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: The fellowEnter Duke, Petruchio.
We have lost him in our spleens, like fools.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come gentlemen,
Now set on roundly; suppose ye have all mistresses,
And mend your pace according,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then have at ye.Exeunt

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, and John.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now to Bologna, my most honoured brother,
