I dare pronounce yea hearty, and safe welcome,
Our loves shall now waylay ye; welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: The same to you brave sir; don Fredrick
Will ye step in, and give the lady notice
Who comes to honour her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Bid her be sudden,
We come to see no curious wench: a nightgown
Will serve the turn: here's one that knows her nearer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I'll tell her what ye say sir. Ex. Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My dear brother,
Ye are a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now will the sport be
To observe her alterations; how like wildfire
She'll leap into your bosom; then seeing me,
Her conscience, and her fears creeping upon her
Dead as a foul at souse, she'll sink.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fair brother,
I must entreat you —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I conceive your mind sir,
I will not chide her: yet ten ducats Duke,
She falls upon he knees, ten more she dare not —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I must not have her frighted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well you shall not:Enter Fred. and Peter.
But like a summer's evening against heat,
Mark how I'll guild he cheeks?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: How now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may sir:
Not to abuse your patience, noble friends,
Nor hold ye off with tedious circumstance,
For you must know, —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What did you say sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone, by heaven removed,
The woman of the house too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Well don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Don John, it is not well, but —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This fellow
Can testify I lie not.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Some four hours after
My master was departed with this gentleman,
My fellow and myself, being sent of business,
(As we must think) of purpose —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hang these circumstances,
They appear like owls, to ill ends.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Now could I eat
The devil in his own broth, I am so tortured.
Gone?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Directly gone, fled, shifted: what would you have me say?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well gentlemen,
Wrong not my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For your dukedom
I will not be a knave sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: He that is
A rot run in his blood.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: But hark ye gentlemen,
Are ye sure ye had her here, did ye not dream this.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Have you your nose sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Then we had her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Since you are so short, believe your having her
Shall suffer more construction.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Let it suffer,
But if I be not clear of all dishonour,
Or practice that may taint my reputation,
And ignorant of where this woman is,
Make me your city's monster.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I believe ye.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I could lie with a witch now, to be revenged
Upon that rascal did this.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Only thus much
I would desire your grace, for my mind gives me
Before night yet she is yours: stop all opinion,
And let no anger out, till full cause call it,
Than every man's own work's to justify him,
And this day let us give to search: my man here
Tells me, by chance he saw out of a window
(Which place he has taken note of) such a face
As our old landladies, he believes the same too,
And by her hood assures it: let's first thither,
For she being found, all's ended.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, for heaven's sake,
And fortune, and thou beest not ever turning,
If there be one firm step in all thy reelings,
Now settle it, and save my hopes: away friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With all my jewels?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: All sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And that money
I left i'th' trunk?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The trunk broke, and that gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Franscisco of the plot?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Gone with the wench too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The mighty pox go with 'em: belike they thought
I was no man of this world, and those trifles
Would but disturb my conscience.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sure they thought sir,
You would not live to persecute 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whore and fiddler,
Why, what a consort have they made? Hen and bacon?
Well my sweet mistress, well good madam Martaile?
You that have hung about my neck, and licked me,
I'll try how handsomely your ladyship
Can hang upon a gallows, there's your masterpiece;
But hark ye sirrah, no imagitionBawd ready above.
Of where they should be?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: None sir, yet we have searched
All places we suspected; I believe sir,
They have taken towards the ports.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Get me a conjurer,
One that can raise a water devil, I'll port 'em;
Play at duck and drake with my money? take heed Fidler;
I'll dance ye by this hand, your fiddlestick
I'll grease of a new fashion, for presuming
To meddle with my degamboys: get me a conjurer,
Inquire me out a man that lets out devils:
None but my C. cliff serve your turn?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I know not —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In every street, tom fool, any blear-eyed people
With red heads, and flat noses can perform it;
Thou shalt know 'em by their half gowns and no breeches:
Mount my mare Fidler? ha boy? up at first dash?
Sit sure, I'll clap a nettle, and a smart one,
Shall make your filly firk: I will find Fidler,
I'll put you to your plunge boy: sirrah meet me
Some two hours hence at home; in the mean time
Find out a conjurer and know his price,
How he will let his devils by the day out,
I'll have 'em, and they be above ground. Exit Ant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Now bless me,
What a mad man is this? I must do something
To please his humour: such a man I'll ask for,
And tell him where he is: but to come near him,
Or have any thing to do with his done devils,
I thank my fear, I dare not, nor I will not. Exit.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, John, Peter, servant with bottles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whether wilt thou lead us?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis hard by sir.
And ten to one this wine goes thither.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Are they grown so merry.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis most likely
She has heard of this good fortune, and determines
To wash her sorrows off.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis so; that house sir
Is it: out of that window certainly
I saw my old mistress's face.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: They are merry indeed,Music.
Hark I hear music too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Excellent music.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Would I were e'en among 'em and alone how,
A palate for the purpose in a corner,
And good rich wine within me; what gay sport
Could I make in an hour now? Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hark a voice too;
Let's not stir yet by any means.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Was this her own voice?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes sure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare one. Enter bawd (Above)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The song confirms her here too: for if ye mark it,
It spoke of liberty, and free enjoying
The happy end of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Look ye there sir,
Do ye know that head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis my good landlady,
I find fear has done all this.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: She I swear,
And now do I know by the hanging of her hood,
She is parcel drunk: shall we go in?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, let 'em take their pleasure,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: When it is highest,Music.
We'll step in, and amaze 'em: peace more music.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This music murders me; what blood have I now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I should know that face. Enter Fran. and exit.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: By this light 'tis he Fredricks,
That bred our first suspicions, the same fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He that we overtook, and overheard too
Discoursing of Constantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Still the same;
Now he slips in.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She must be here sir:
This is the very fellow, I told your graceEnter Fran.
We found upon the way; and what his talk was.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why, sure I know this fellow; yes, 'tis he,
Francisco, Antonio's boy, a rare musician,
He taught my sister on the lute, and is ever
(She loves his voice so well) about her: certain,
Without all doubt she is here: it must be so.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Here? that's no question: what should our hen o'th game else
Do here without her? if she be not here
(I am so confident) let your grace believe,
We two are arrant rascals, and have abused ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I say so too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why there's the hood again now,
The guard that guides us; I know the fabric of it.
And know the old tree of that saddle yet, 'twas made of
A hunting hood, observe it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Who shall enter?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I'll make one.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ay, another.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But so carry it,
That all her joys flow not together.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we told her,
Your grace would none of her?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By no means signior,
'Twould turn her wild, stark frantic.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Or assured her —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nothing of that? starve nature? this ye may sir.
That the conditions of our fear yet stand
On nice and dangerous knittings: or that a little
I seem to doubt the child.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Would I could draw her
To hate your grace with these things.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come let's enter,Exit. Pet. and Joh. music.
And now he sees me not, I'll search her soundly.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now luck of all sides.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: Doubt it not: more music:
Sure she has heard some comfort.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes, stand still sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is the maddest song.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Applied for certainClaping of a door.
To some strange melancholy she is laden with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now all the sport begins — hark?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: They are amongst 'em,
The fears now, and the shakings? Trampling above.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Our old lady
(Hark how they run) is even now at this instantCease music petr. and John within.
Ready to lose her head piece by don John,
Or creeping through a cat hole.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bring 'em down,
And you sir, follow me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He's angry with 'em,
I must not suffer this.
Bowl down the bawd thereJohn within.
Old erra mater: you lady lechery
For the good will I bear to'th game, most tenderly
Shall be led out, and lashed.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, John, whore, and bawd, with Francisco.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is this Constantia?
Why gentlemen? what do you mean? is this she?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: I am Constantia sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A whore ye are sir.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: 'Tis very true: I am a whore indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She will not lie yet, though she steal.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A plain whore,
If you please to employ me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And an impudent —

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Plain dealing now is impudence.
One if you will sir, can show ye as much sport
In one half hour, and with as much variety,
As a far wiser woman can in half a year:
For there my way lies.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is she not drunk too?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A little guilded o'er sir,
Old sack, old sack boys.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This is salient.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: A brave bold quean.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is this your certainty?
Do ye know the man ye wrong thus, gentlemen?
Is this the woman meant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That your landlady?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Am I a person
To be your sport gentlemen?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I do believe now certain
I am a knave; but how, or when —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bawd to this piece of pie meat.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: A poor gentlewoman
That lies in town, about law business,
An't like your worships.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You shall have law, believe it.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: I'll show your mastership my case.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By no means,
I had rather see a custard.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: My dead husband
Left it even thus sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Bless mine eyes from blasting,
I was never so frighted with a case.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: And so sir —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Enough, put up good velvet head.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What are you two now,
By your own free confessions?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What you shall think us,
Though to myself I am certain, and my life
Shall make that good and perfect, or fall with it.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We are sure of nothing (Fred) that's the truth on't:
I do not think my name's don John, nor dare not
Believe any thing that concerns me, but my debts,
Nor those in way of payment: things are so carried,
What to entreat your grace, or how to tell ye
We are, or we are not, is passed my cunning,
But I would fain imagine we are honest,
And of my conscience, I should fight in't —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thus then,
For we may be all abused.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis possible,
For how should this concern them?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here let's part —
Until tomorrow this time: we to our way,
To make this doubt out, and you to your way;
Pawning our honours then to meet again,
When if she be not found.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We stand engaged
To answer any worthy way we are called to.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We ask no more.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Ye have done with us then?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No dame.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But is her name Constantia?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes a movable
Belonging to a friend of mine: come out fiddler,
What say you to this lady; be not fearful?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of my master's pleasure,
I say she is a whore, and that she has robbed him,
Hoping his hurts would kill him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Who provoked me?
Nay sirrah squeak, I'll see your treble strings
Tied up too; if I hang, I'll spoil your piping,
Your sweet face shall not save ye.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thou damned impudence,
And thou dried devil; where's the officer?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: He's here sir. Enter officer.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Lodge these safe till I send for 'em;
Let none come to 'em, nor no noise be heard
Of where they are, or why: away.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By this hand
A handsome whore: now will I be arrested,
And brought home to this officers: a stout whore,
I love such stirring ware: pox of this business,
A man must haunt out morsels for another,
And starve himself: a quick-eyed whore, that's wildfire,
And makes the blood dance through the veins like billows.
I will reprieve this whore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, good luck with ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As much attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Tomorrow certain —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we outlive this night sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come don John,
We have something now to do.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am sure I would have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If she be not found, we must fight.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
I have not fought a great while.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If we die —

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: There's so much money saved in lechery. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio below, and Vechio above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It should be hereabouts .

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Your grace is right,
This is the house I know it.

sp.speaker: Voch.
sp.l: Grace?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis further
By the description we received.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Good my lord the Duke,
Believe me, for I know it certainly,
This is the very house.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: My lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Pray heaven this man prove right now.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Believe it, he's a most sufficient scholar,
And can do rare tricks this way; for a figure,
Or raising an appearance, whole Christendom
Has not a better; I have heard strange wonders of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But can he show us where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Most certain,
And for what cause too she departed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Knock then,
For I am great with expectation,
Till this man satisfy me: I fear the Spaniards,
Yet they appear brave fellows: can he tell us?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: With a wet finger, whether they be false.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Who's within here? Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your grace may enter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How can he know me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He knows all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And you sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: What do you call his name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why, Peter Vechio.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: They say he can raise devils,
Can he make 'em
Tell truth too, when he has raised 'em? for believe it,
These devils are the lyingst rascals.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He can compel 'em.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: With what? can he
Tie squibs in their tails, and fire the truth out?
Or make 'em eat a bawling Puritan,
Whose sanctified zeal shall rumble like an earthquake?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: With spells man?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I with spoons as soon, dost thou think
The devil such an ass as people make him?
Such a poor coxcomb? such a penny foot post?
Compelled with cross and pile to run of errands?
With Asteroth, and Behemoth, and Belfagor?
Why should he shake at sounds, that lives in a smith's forge?
Or if he do —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Without all doubt he does John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why should not bilbo raise him, or a pair of bullions,
They go as big as any? or an unshod car,
When he goes tumble, tumble o'er the stones,
Like Anacreon's drunken verses, make us tremble?
These make as fell a noise; methinks the colic
Well handled, and fed with small beer —

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the virtue —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: The virtue? nay, and goodness fetch him up once,
Has lost a friend of me; the wise old gentleman
Knows when, and how; I'll lay this hand to two pence,
Let all the conjurers in Christendom,
With all their spells, and virtues call upon him,
And I but think upon a wench, and follow it,
He shall be sooner mine than theirs; where's virtue?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art the most sufficient, (I'll say for thee)
Not to believe a thing —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: O sir, slow credit
Is the best child of knowledge; I'll go with ye,
And if he can do any thing, I'll think
As you would have me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let's inquire a long,
For certain we are not far off.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Nor much nearer. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: You lost her yesternight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How think you sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is your name Vechio?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And you can show me
These; things you promise.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your grace's word bound to me,
No hand of law shall seize me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: As I live sir —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And as I live, that can do something too sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I take your promises: stay here a little,
Till I prepare some ceremonies, and I'll satisfy ye.
The lady's name's Constantia?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I come straight. Exit Vech.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sure he's a learned man.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The most now living;
Did your grace mark when we told all these circumstances,
However and anon he bolted from us
To use his studies help?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now I think rather
To talk with some familiar.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not unlikely,
For sure he has 'em subject.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How could he else
Tell when she went, and who went with her?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Or hit upon mine honour: or assure me
The lady loved me dear?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas so.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Now,
I do beseech your grace sit down, and you sir;
Nay pray sit close like brothers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A rare fellow.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And what ye see, stir not at, nor use a word,
Until I ask ye; for what shall appear
Is but weak apparition and thin air
Not to be held, nor spoken too. Knocking within.

div.stage: John, Frederick, and a servant within.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We are counselled —

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: What noise is that without there?

sp.speaker: Fred. within.
sp.l: We must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Servant within.
sp.l: He's busy gentlemen.

sp.speaker: John. Within.
sp.l: That's all one friend,
We must, and will speak with him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let 'em in sir,
We know their tongues and business, 'tis our own,
And in this very cause that we now come for,
They also come to be instructed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Let 'em in then:
Sit down, I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Duke before us,
Now we shall sure know something.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Not a question,
But make your eyes, your tongues —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This is a strange juggler,
Neither indent before hand for his payment,
Nor know the breadth of the business; sure his devil
Comes out of Lapland were they sell men winds,
For dead drink, and old doublets.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Let him, he cannot raise my devil.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Appear, appear,
And you soft winds so clear,
That dance upon the leaves, and make them sing
Gentle love-lays to the spring,
Gilding all the vales below
With your verdure as ye blow,
Raise these forms from under ground
With a soft and happy sound. Soft music.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: This is an honest conjurer, and a pretty poet;
I like his words well, there's no bombast in 'em,
But do you think now, he can cudgel up the devil,
With this short staff of verses?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Peace the spirits —2. Shapes of women pass by.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Nay, and they be no worse —

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Do ye know these faces?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still upon your lives then: and mark what follows:
Away, away.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: These devils do not paint sure?
Have they no sweeter shapes in hell? Constantia passes by.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hark now John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I marry, this moves something like, this devil
Carries some metal in her gate.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I find ye,
You would see her face unveiled?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Be uncovered.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: See how she blushes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Fredrick,
This devil for my money; this is she boy,
Why thou shake? I burn.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still, and silent.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: She looks back at me; now she smiles sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I must rise, or burst. Exit. Const.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ye see what follows —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O gentle sir this shape again.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I cannot,
'Tis all dissolved again: this was the figure.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The very same sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No hope once more to see it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: You might have kept it longer, had ye spared it,
Now 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No means to find it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Yes that there is: sit still a while, there's wine
To thaw the wonder from your hearts: drink well sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This conjurer is a right good fellow too,
A lad of mettle; two such devils more
Would make me a conjurer: what wine is it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hollock.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The devil's in it then, look how it dances?
Well, if I be —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are all before ye,
That's your best comfort sir.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Byth' mass brave wine;
Nay, and the devils live in this hell, I dare venture
Within these two months yet to be delivered
Of a large legion of 'em. Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here 'a comes,
Silence of all sides gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vec.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Observe a stricter temper, and you too gallants,
You'll be deluded all else. This merry devil
That next appears, for such a one you'll find it,
Must be called up by a strange incantation,
A song, and I must sing it: pray bear with me,
And pardon my rude pipe; for yet ere parting
Twenty to one I please ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We are armed sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor shall you see us more transgress.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What think'st thou
Now John?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why, now do I think Fredrick,
(And it I think amiss heaven pardon me,)
This honest conjurer, with some four or five
Of his good fellow devils, and myself,
Shall be yet drunk ere midnight. Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why, this is the song Fredrick: twenty pound now
To see but our don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace it appears.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I cannot peace: devils in French hoods Fredrick?
Satan's old sirings?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: She, boy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: She, boy, I say.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: She, boy.
The very child too Fredrick;

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She laughs on us
Aloud John, has the devil these affections?
I do believe 'tis she indeed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Stand still.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I will not;
Who calls Jeronimo from his naked bed?
Sweet lady, was it you? If thou beest the devil,
First, having crossed myself, to keep out wildfire,
Then said some special prayers to defend me
Against thy most unhallowed hood: have at thee.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Hold sir, I am no devil.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I am your very landlady.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I defy thee:
Thus as st. Dunstan blew the devil's nose
With a pair of tongs, even so right worshipful —

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Sweet son, I am old Gillion.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This is no spirit.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Art thou old Gillian, flesh and bone?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I am son.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.p: Sit still sir, now I'll show you all. Ex. Vech.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Where's thy bottle?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: Here, I beseech ye son —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: For I know the devil
Cannot assume that shape.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis she John, certain —

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: A hog's pox o'your mouldy chaps, what make you
Tumbling and juggling here?

sp.speaker: Landlady
sp.l: I am quit now signior,
For all the pranks you played, and railings at me,
For to tell true, out of a trick I put
Upon your high behaviours, which was a lie,
But then it served my turn, I drew the lady
Unto my kinsman's here, only to torture
Your donships for a day or two; and secure her
Out of all thoughts of danger: here she comes now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May I yet speak?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes, and embrace her too,
For one that loves you dearer —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Blush not, I will not chide ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: To add more
Unto the joy I know, I bring ye, see sir,
The happy fruit of all our vows.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Heaven's blessing
Be round about thee ever.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Pray bless me to,
For if your grace be well instructed this way,
You'll find the keeping half the getting.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I'll tell ye that anon.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: 'Tis true this gentleman
'Has done a charity worthy your favour,
And let him have it dear sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My best lady
She has, and ever shall have: so must you sir,
To whom I am equal bound, as to my being.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your grace's humble servants —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why kneel you sir?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: For pardon for my boldness: yet 'twas harmless
And all the art I have sir; those your grace saw
Which you thought spirits, were my neighbour's children
Whom I instruct in grammar, here, and music;
Their shapes, the people's fond opinions,
Believing I can conjure, and oft repairing
To know of things stolen from 'em, I keep about me,
And always have in readiness; by conjecture
Out of their own confessions, I oft tell 'em
Things, that by chance have fallen out so: which way
(Having the persons here, I knew you sought for)
I wrought upon your grace: my end is mirth,
And pleasing, if I can, all parties.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I believe it,
For you have pleased me truly: so well pleased me,
That when I shall forget it —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here's old Antonio,
I spied him at a window, coming mainly
I know about his whore, the man you light on,
As yond discovered unto me: good your grace,
Let's stand by all, 'twill be a mirth above all,
To observe his pelting fury.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: About a wench sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A young whore that has robbed him,

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: But do you know sir,
Where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, and will make that perfect —

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I am instructed well then.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If he come
To have a devil showed him, by all means
Let me be he, I can roar rarely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Be so,
But take heed to his anger.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Slip in quickly,
There you shall find suits of all sorts: when I call,
Be ready and come forward. Ex. all but vech.
Who's there come in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you the conjurer?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sir I can do a little
That way, if you please to employ me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Presently show me a devil that can tell —

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Where your wench is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are i'th' right; as also where the fiddler
That was consenting to her.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ye there sir,
Ye shall know presently: can ye pray heartily?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, is your devil so furious?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I must show ye
A form, may chance affright ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He must fart fire then:
Take you no care for me.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ascend Asterth,Enter don John like a spirit.
Why, when, appear I say — now question him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is my whore don devil?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Gone to China,
To be the great cham's mistress.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's a lie devil:
Where are my jewels?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Pawned for petticoats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That may be; where's the fiddler?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Condemned to th' gallows,
For robbing of a mill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The lyingst devil
That e'er I dealt withal, and the unlikeliest:
What was that rascal hurt me?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who was he?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye here conjurer,
Dare you venture your devil?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I'll venture my dagger;
Have at your devils pate; do ye mew? Enter all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hold there,
I do command ye hold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this the devil?
Why conjurer —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Has been a devil to you sir.
But now you shall forget all: your whores safe,
And all your jewels: your boy too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Now the devil indeed
Lay his ten claws upon thee, for my pate
Finds what it is to be a fend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All safe?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray ye know this person: all's right now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your grace
May now command me then: but where's my whore?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ready to go to whipping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My whore whipped?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, your whore without doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whipped? pray gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, would you have her once more rob ye? the young boy
You may forgive, he was enticed.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: The whore sir,
Would rather carry pity: a handsome whore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A gentleman I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let's in all.
And if we see contrition in your whore sir,
Much may be done.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now my dear fair, to you,
And the full consummation of my vow.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Aptness for mirth to all, this instant night
Thalia hath prepared for your delight,
Her choice and curious viands, in each part,
Seasoned with rarities of wit, as art;
Nor fear I to be taxed for a vain boast,
My promise will find credit with the most,
When they know ingenuous Fletcher made it, he
Being in himself a perfect comedy.
And some sit here, I doubt not dare a verre,
Living he made that house a theater
Which he pleased to frequent; and thus much we
Could not but pay to his loud memory.
For ourselves we do entreat that you would not
Expect strange turns, and windings in the plot,
Objects of state, and now and then a rhyme,
To gall particular persons, with the time;
Or that his to wring muse hath made her flight
Nearer your apprehension than your sight:
But if that sweet expressions, quick conceit,
Familiar language, fashioned to the weight
Of such as speak it, have the power to raise
Your grace to us, with trophies to his praise:
We may profess, presuming on his skill,
If his chances please not you, our fortune's ill.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: We have not held you long, nor do I see
One brow in this selected company
Assuring a dislike, our pains were eased.
Could we be confident that all rise pleased:
But such ambition soars too high: if we
Have satisfied the best, and they agree
In a fair censure, we have our reward;
And in them armed, desire no surer guard.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
